problems.title: Any Set is Compact in Co-finite Topology
problems.problem: Suppose $X$ is an infinite set equipped with the cofinite topology. Prove that $X$ is compact.
problems.hint: • The complement of any non-empty open set has only finitely many elements. Now use the definition of compactness to show that the space is compact.
problems.solution: Let $\mathcal{C} \coloneqq \{ U_\alpha \}_{\alpha \in I} $ be an open cover of $X$. Since for each $\alpha \in I$ the set $U_\alpha $ is open and hence $U_{\alpha } = \varnothing $ or $X \setminus U_\alpha $ is a finite set. Let $x_0 \in X$ and let $x_0 \in U_{\alpha _0}$ for some $\alpha _0 \in I$. This implies $X \setminus U_{\alpha _0}$ is finite, that is, \[ X \setminus U_{\alpha _0} = \{x_1, x_2, \dots, x_k\}. \] Choose $\alpha _i \in I$ such that $x_i \in U_{\alpha _i}$. Thus, we have a finite subcover of $\mathcal{C} $, namely, $\{ U_{\alpha _0}, U_{\alpha _1}, \dots, U_{\alpha _k} \} $. Therefore, $X$ is compact.

problems.title: Some Problem
problems.problem:
On the real line $\mathbb{R} $, consider the collection of subsets 
    \[
        \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow } \coloneqq \{ \varnothing , \mathbb{R}  \}  \cup \{ (-\infty ,a): a \in \mathbb{R}  \}  .
    \] 
    Show that $\mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$ is a topology on $\mathbb{R} $.
problems.hint:
• If $\{ U_\alpha = (-\infty ,\alpha ) : \alpha \in I \}\subset \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$, then consider the supremum of all such $\alpha $.
  • If $F_i = (-\infty , \alpha _i) \in \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$, $i =1,2,\dots,n $, then consider the minimum of such $\alpha _i$.
problems.solution:
Recall that $\mathcal{T} $ is a topology on a set $X$, if the following holds:
  1. $X, \varnothing \in \mathcal{T} $;
  2. If $U_\alpha \in \mathcal{T} $ for $\alpha \in I$, then $ \cup U_\alpha \in \mathcal{T} $;
  3. If $F_i \in \mathcal{T} $ for $i = 1,2,\dots,n$, then $ \cap F_i \in \mathcal{T} $.
We will verify each of these conditions.
  1. True as it is given that $\varnothing , \mathbb{R} \in \mathcal{T}_{\leftarrow }.$
  2. Let $\{ U_\alpha = (-\infty ,\alpha ) : \alpha \in I \}\subset \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$, where $I$ is an index set. We need to show that $ \cup (-\infty ,\alpha ) \in \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$. Consider the collection $\mathcal{A} = \{\alpha \in \mathbb{R} : \alpha \in I\}$, and let $\alpha _0 = \sup \mathcal{A} $. It is clear that $\alpha _0 \in \mathbb{R} $ and also $ \cup U_\alpha = (-\infty ,\alpha _0)\in \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$.
  3. Let $F_i = (-\infty , \alpha _i) \in \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$, $i =1,2,\dots,n $. Since the collection $\{ \alpha _i \in \mathbb{R} : i = 1,2,\dots, n \} $ is finite, let $\alpha _0$ is the minimum of the collection and $ \cap (-\infty ,\alpha _i) = (-\infty ,\alpha _0) \in \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$.
Thus, $\mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$ is a topology on $\mathbb{R} $.

problems.title: Fixed point set of a continuous function is closed
problems.problem:
Let $\mathbb{R} $ be equipped with the usual Euclidean topology. If $f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} $ is a continuous function, show that the set of points which are left fixed by $f$ is a closed subset of $\mathbb{R} $.
Also generalize the same for a Hausdorff topological space $X$ and a continuous function $f: X \to X$.
problems.hint:
• Consider $g(x) = f(x) - x$.
  • Use the condition that the topology is Hausdorff. Show that the complement is open.
problems.solution:
Let \[ \mathcal{F} = \{ x\in \mathbb{R} : f(x) = x \} . \] We need to show that $\mathcal{F} $ is closed subset of $\mathbb{R} .$ Consider a function $g: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} $ \[ g(x) = f(x) - x. \] It is clear that $g$ is continuous and $\mathcal{F} = g^{-1} (\{ 0 \} )$. Since $\{ 0 \} $ is a closed set and $g$ is continuous, $\mathcal{F} = g^{-1} \{ 0 \} $ is closed in $\mathbb{R} $.
This problem can be solved for an arbitrary Hausdorff topological space $X$ and a continuous function on $X$. More precisely, if $X$ is a topological space which is Hausdorff and $f: X \to X$ is continuous, then the fixed point set of $f$ is closed in $X$ . We will show that $\mathcal{F} ^c = \mathbb{R} \setminus \mathcal{F} $ is open in $\mathbb{R} $. Let $a \in \mathcal{F} ^c$, which implies $f(a) \neq a$. As the standard topology on $\mathbb{R} $ is Hausdorff, we can find neighborhoods $U \text{ and } V$ of $f(a) \text{ and } a$, respectively, such that $U \cap V = \varnothing .$ Since $f$ is continuous, $f^{-1} (V)$ is an open neighborhood of $a$ and hence $U \cap f^{-1} (V)$ is an open neighborhood of $a$. We now claim that $\mathcal{O} \coloneqq U \cap f^{-1} (V) \subseteq \mathcal{F} ^c$.
To the contrary, if $x \in \mathcal{O} \cap \mathcal{F} $, then $x \in U, x \in f^{-1} (V)$ and $x \in \mathcal{F} $ which implies $f(x) = x$. Since \[ x \in f^{-1} (V) \implies f(x) \in V \implies x = f(x) \in V \implies x \in U \cap V, \] a contradiction.

problems.title: A basis for R^2
problems.problem: Let $\mathcal{B} $ be the collection of all open discs with all possible radii and center at any point. Show that $\mathcal{B} $ is a basis for the usual topology on $\mathbb{R} ^2$.
problems.hint: • Draw pictures to show that if $x \in B_1 \cap B_2$ for some $B_1, B_2 \in \mathcal{B}$, then there exists $B_3 \in \mathcal{B}$ such that \[ x \in B_3 \subseteq B_1 \cap B_2. \]
problems.solution:
Recall that the definition of a basis for a topology on $X$. A collection $\mathcal{B}$ of subsets of $X$ is called a basis for a topology on $X$ if it satisfies the following two conditions:
  1. Covering condition: For every $x \in X$, there exists $B \in \mathcal{B}$ such that $x \in B$.
  2. Intersection condition: If $x \in B_1 \cap B_2$ for some $B_1, B_2 \in \mathcal{B}$, then there exists $B_3 \in \mathcal{B}$ such that \[ x \in B_3 \subseteq B_1 \cap B_2. \]
Note that \[ \mathcal{B} = \left\{ D(\mathbf{x} ,r): \mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R} ^2, \text{ and } r > 0 \right\}, \] where \[ D(\mathbf{x} ,r) = \left\{ \mathbf{y} \in \mathbb{R} ^2 : \lVert \mathbf{x} - \mathbf{y} \rVert < r \right\} . \]
  1. Let $\mathbf{a} \in \mathbb{R} ^2$. Then $\mathbf{a} \in D(\mathbf{a} , 1)$ and hence the covering condition satisfies.
  2. Let $B_1 = D(\mathbf{x} _1,r_1)$ and $B_2 = D(\mathbf{x} _2,r_2)$ be elements of $\mathcal{B}$, and suppose that \[ \mathbf{x} \in B_1 \cap B_2. \] Then \[ \|\mathbf{x} - \mathbf{x} _1\| < r_1 \quad \text{and} \quad \|\mathbf{x} - \mathbf{x} _2\| < r_2. \] Define \[ \varepsilon = \min \{ r_1 - \|\mathbf{x} - \mathbf{x} _1\|,\; r_2 - \|\mathbf{x} - \mathbf{x} _2\| \} > 0. \] In the below picture, $\varepsilon = \min \{ r,s \} $.
Consider the open disc $B_3 = D(x,\varepsilon)$. For any $y \in B_3$, we have \begin{align*} \|\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{x} _1\| \le \|\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{x} \| + \|\mathbf{x} - \mathbf{x} _1\| < \varepsilon + \|\mathbf{x} - \mathbf{x} _1\| \le r_1, \end{align*} so $\mathbf{y} \in B_1$. Similarly, $\mathbf{y} \in B_2$. Thus, \[ \mathbf{x} \in B_3 \subseteq B_1 \cap B_2, \] Since $\mathcal{B}$ satisfies both basis axioms, it is a basis for a topology on $\mathbb{R}^2$.

problems.title: NBHM PhD 2005 - Distance between x-axis and the graph y = 1/x
problems.hint: • $d(A,B) = \inf \{ d(a,b): a \in A \text{ and } B \in B\}$.
problems.solution:
Given that \begin{align*} A & = \{ (x,y) \in \mathbb{R} ^2: y = 0 \} \text{ and } \\ B & = \{ (x,y) \in \mathbb{R} ^2: xy = 1 \}. \end{align*} We need to find the distance between $A$ and $B$. Observe that for a fix $ y = \left( b, \frac{1}{b} \right) \in B$ \begin{align*} d(A,b) & = \inf \{ d(x,y): x \in A\} \\ & = d\left( (b,0), \left( b, \frac{1}{b} \right) \right) \\ & = \frac{1}{\vert b \vert }. \end{align*}
Thus, \begin{align*} d(A, B) & = \inf \{ d(x,y): x \in A \text{ and } y \in B\} \\ & = \inf \left\{ \frac{1}{\vert b \vert } : b \in \mathbb{R} \setminus \{ 0 \} \right\} \\ & = 0. \end{align*}

problems.title: A discontinuous function is continuous in lower limit topology
problems.problem:
Let $\mathcal{T} _s $ be the usual topology on the real line $\mathbb{R} $ and $\mathcal{T} _u$ be the upper limit topology on $\mathbb{R} $ which is generated by the open-closed intervals $(a, b]$. Furthermore, let $f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} $ be defined by \[ f(x) = \begin{cases} x, &\text{ if } x \leq 1 ;\\ x + 2, &\text{ if } x > 1. \end{cases} \]
  1. Show that $f$ is not continuous if both side we have $\mathcal{T} _s$ topology.
  2. Show that $f$ is continuous if both side we have $\mathcal{T} _u$ topology.
problems.hint:
• For the standard topology look at the graph of the function and $U = (-3,2)$ and see what is the inverse image.
  • For the upper limit topology, show that the preimage of basis is open, that is, $f^{-1} ((a,b])$ is open.
problems.solution:
The given function is \[ f(x) = \begin{cases} x, &\text{ if } x \leq 1 ;\\ x + 2, &\text{ if } x > 1. \end{cases} \] We will show that this function is not continuous if we have the standard topology and continuous if we put the upper limit topology. Just to recall that a function is continuous if it pulls back an open set to an open set. Since $f^{-1} \left( \cup U_{\alpha } \right) = \cup f^{-1} (U_\alpha )$, so it is enough to check for basis.
  1. Look at the figure below. Take $U = (-3,2) \in \mathcal{T} _s$. Then \begin{align*} f^{-1} (U) & = f^{-1} \left( (-3,1) \cup (1,2) \right) \\ & = f^{-1} (-3, 1] \cup f^{-1} (1,2) \\ & = (-3,1] \cup \varnothing = (-3,1] \notin \mathcal{T} _s. \end{align*} Hence, $f$ is not continuous with the standard topology.
  2. Now to show that $f$ is continuous with the lower limit topology, we will show that $f^{-1} ((a,b])$ is open for any $a,b \in \mathbb{R} $. Note that \[ f^{-1} ((a,b]) = \begin{cases} (a,b], &\text{ if } a < b \leq 1 ;\\ (a,1], &\text{ if } a < b \leq 3 ;\\ (a,b-2], &\text{ if } a < 1 < 3 < b ;\\ \varnothing, &\text{ if } 1\leq a < b \leq 3;\\ (1, b-2], &\text{ if } 1\leq a < 3 < b;\\ (a-2, b-2], &\text{ if } 3 \leq a < b. \end{cases} \] Thus, in either case $f^{-1} ((a,b]) in \mathcal{T} _u$ and hence $f $ is continuous.
